vectorData.altText: 23. What region of this organ is indicated by the letters B?

That’s right!  ‘B’ indicates white pulp of the spleen. Splenic white pulp consists of lymphoid tissue, the densely packed nuclei of lymphocytes provides the basophilic appearance. This region can be identified by the basophilic lymphoid nodules.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

The spleen is enclosed in a dense, irregular connective tissue capsule (A). It is highly eosinophilic due to its complement of collagen type I fibres. Trabeculae extend into the substance of the spleen and contain major blood vessels. The parenchyma of the spleen is divided into white pulp (B) and red pulp (C).

The splenic white pulp     consists of lymphoid tissue. Its densely-packed nuclei give the splenic white pulp a basophilic appearance. Splenic nodules (D) are adjacent to the central arterioles (E), and often contain a more pale-staining germinal centre (F) consisting of activated B-lymphocytes. The central arterioles branch from the trabecular arteries. Periarteriolar lymphatic sheaths, PALS (G), dominated by T-lymphocytes, surround the central arterioles. 
The splenic red pulp contains all blood elements and is therefore eosinophilic due to the predominance of red blood cells. It consists of splenic sinusoids (H), blood-filled spaces, separated by splenic cords (I), which consist of loose connective tissue dominated by macrophages, plasma cells and lymphocytes. The sheathed arterioles of the red pulp are surrounded by macrophages.
